cluster_classes.class_description: Distinct developmental stages in the butterfly life cycle, specifically the feeding larval (caterpillar) stage and the metamorphic pupa (chrysalis) stage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both entities are defined as developmental life stages within the butterfly life cycle.

members.entity_description: Protective pupa casing formed by a caterpillar during the pupal stage, enclosing it as it undergoes metamorphosis into a butterfly.
Adult stage that the caterpillar develops into after metamorphosis.
The larval life stage of a butterfly, immediately after the egg hatches, during which the organism is a caterpillar that feeds and grows on host plants before forming a pupa.
The third developmental life stage of a butterfly, in which the organism is enclosed in a chrysalis and undergoes metamorphosis from larva to adult.

cluster_classes.class_description: Entities describing the butterfly at or immediately after the adult (imago) stage, including the newly emerged adult and its readiness for first flight.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The fourth and final stage of the butterfly's life cycle is the adult stage... ready to take flight for the first time.

members.entity_description: Butterfly immediately after exiting the chrysalis, with soft, wrinkled wings.
Butterfly’s ability to fly once its wings are fully developed.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts describing the butterfly’s developmental process from early stages to its final admired adult state.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: from egg through larva and pupa to adult … butterfly fluttering by … moment of beauty and grace

members.entity_description: The full developmental path of a butterfly from egg through larva and pupa to adult.
The state of the butterfly as a fully developed, aesthetically admired adult in flight.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts related to the adult life stage of butterflies, including the stage itself and its characteristic duration.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: final, mature life stage of a butterfly… and the characteristic temporal duration of the butterfly’s adult stage

members.entity_description: The final, winged life stage of a butterfly following the pupa (chrysalis), during which the organism is fully developed, capable of flight, feeding, mating, and reproduction.
Duration of life of butterflies in the adult stage, typically days to weeks.

args.new_description: Entities describing the final, winged adult (imago) stage of butterflies, including the newly emerged adult, its readiness for flight, and properties specific to the adult stage such as lifespan.
args.justification: Both classes focus on the same biological concept—the adult butterfly life stage—with overlapping scope (adult stage and its characteristics), so they should be unified into a single adult-stage class.
Entity 'butterfly' is explicitly the adult life stage and belongs with the unified adult-stage class rather than a mixed life-stages class.

Entity 'moment of beauty and grace' refers to the aesthetic state of the fully developed adult butterfly in flight, aligning better with the adult life-stage class than with the full life-cycle process.

splits.name: Butterfly pupa casing (chrysalis)
splits.description: The protective casing formed around the butterfly pupa (chrysalis), a physical structure enclosing the organism during metamorphosis.

args.justification: ClsC_da99310a currently mixes biological life stages (larva, pupa stage, adult) with a distinct physical structure (chrysalis); the chrysalis should be split into its own structural class.

args.new_name: Butterfly immature life stages (larva and pupa)
args.new_description: Developmental life stages of butterflies before adulthood, specifically the feeding larval (caterpillar) stage and the pupal stage during which metamorphosis occurs.
args.justification: After moving the adult stage out and splitting the chrysalis structure, the remaining class cleanly represents larval and pupal life stages and should be renamed and grouped accordingly.

args.new_description: The final, winged life stage of a butterfly following the pupa (chrysalis), including newly emerged adults, their acquisition of flight, and adult-specific properties such as lifespan.
args.justification: The merged adult-stage class should be explicitly labeled and connected to the broader butterfly development and life cycle group.

args.new_description: The chrysalis, a stationary, protective casing that encloses the butterfly during the pupal stage of metamorphosis.
args.justification: The newly split chrysalis structure class needs a clear label and assignment to the butterfly development and life cycle group.

args.new_description: The overall developmental process of a butterfly from egg through larva and pupa to the adult stage.
args.justification: With the adult aesthetic state moved out, this class should be clarified as the full metamorphic process and aligned under the common butterfly development and life cycle group.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes focus on the same biological concept—the adult butterfly life stage—with overlapping scope (adult stage and its characteristics), so they should be unified into a single adult-stage class.
Entity 'butterfly' is explicitly the adult life stage and belongs with the unified adult-stage class rather than a mixed life-stages class.

Entity 'moment of beauty and grace' refers to the aesthetic state of the fully developed adult butterfly in flight, aligning better with the adult life-stage class than with the full life-cycle process.
ClsC_da99310a currently mixes biological life stages (larva, pupa stage, adult) with a distinct physical structure (chrysalis); the chrysalis should be split into its own structural class.

executed_decisions.justification: The newly split chrysalis structure class needs a clear label and assignment to the butterfly development and life cycle group.

executed_decisions.justification: With the adult aesthetic state moved out, this class should be clarified as the full metamorphic process and aligned under the common butterfly development and life cycle group.
